title: 6 of the best ever Blue Peter makes, to take you back to your childhood
text:
6 of the best ever Blue Peter makes, from the 60s, 70s, 80s and 90s, to take you back to your childhood
- Blue Peter has been running for more than 66 years
- During that time, its presenters have shown viewers how to make an extraordinary range of items
- Below are some of the best Blue Peter ‘makes’ from down the decades
During its remarkable 66-year run, Blue Peter has proved there is nothing you can’t do with some sticky-back plastic, an empty washing-up bottle, a few old coat hangers and a bit of imagination.
Between them, the show’s many presenters have shown children across the UK how to craft all manner of objects from items that would otherwise have ended up in the bin.

It’s fair to say that some of the programme’s legendary ‘makes’ have been more impressive than others.
Below are five of Blue Peter’s best-ever crafting projects, and one of the strangest, from presenters including Valerie Singleton, Janet Ellis and Anthea Turner.
One has gone down in legend, another was a serious fire risk, and a third was out of this world.
Do you remember any of these Blue Peter ‘makes’, and did you try them yourself? If not, it’s not too late to give it a go.

Blake’s Seven teleporter bracelet
The sci-fi classic Blake’s Seven was one of the most popular TV programmes of the late 70s and early 80s, when many children dreamed of owning one of the teleporter bracelets worn by the crew of the Scorpio.
In 1983, Blue Peter presenter Janet Ellis showed youngsters how to make their own teleporter using only an old margarine tub, card, paper, buttons, ribbon, silver paint and glue.
There was nothing like it in the shops at the time, it cost just 40p to make and it looked pretty impressive, perhaps better even than the show’s notoriously dodgy sets. How long it would last is another matter.
Dougal shoulder bag
The Magic Roundabout was perhaps the most iconic children’s TV show of the 60s and 70s, and Dougal was its most beloved character.

Hide Ad
Advertisement
Hide Ad
So it’s no surprise the world-weary Skye terrier ended up featuring on a classic Blue Peter make in 1973.
Lesley Judd showed young viewers how to make a stylish Dougal shoulder bag, using a strip of denim, yellow felt for his shaggy fur, some glue and a needle and thread.
Only basic sewing skills were required, and the plaited shoulder strap made it one of the more stylish, practical and durable of Blue Peter makes.
Tracy Island
This was the mother of all Blue Peter makes.
Tracy Island, the secret hideaway of the Thunderbirds, was one of the most coveted toys in Christmas 1992.
Advertisement
Hide Ad
Advertisement
Hide Ad
Many shops sold out and if you were lucky enough to find one it would cost you £34.99 - equivalent to around £78 today.
Thankfully, Blue Peter presenter Anthea Turner came to the rescue of parents everywhere by showing youngsters how they could make their own version for next to nothing.
It was one of the show’s most ambitious makes, and the list of materials required was extensive, even if they were mostly things you could get for free.
But the end result was seriously impressive, and the BBC was flooded with requests for copies of the instruction sheet after the show aired in January 1993.

Hide Ad
Advertisement
Hide Ad
It was the small details that made this such an impressive build, like the sandpaper beaches, the sawdust mixed with paint to create the grass, and the pipe cleaner palm trees.
This was one of the stranger Blue Peter makes, but if it got just one child to tidy up after themself, any parent would surely say it was worth it.
Yvette Fielding showed viewers how to make their own ‘revolting Beastie box’ to ‘gobble up all your mess’ in the 90s.
All you needed was a grocery box, some sticky-back plastic, an old loo roll to make the googly eyes, an empty yoghurt pot for the fangs, and some wool for the fur.

It might have helped encourage youngsters to keep their rooms clean, but how many parents were left cleaning up the mess their children had created making the spooky container.
Advent crown
This was a perennial favourite Blue Peter make, rolled out year after year at Christmas time.
The Advent crown featured four candles, one to be lit each week in the run-up to Christmas, in the days before most children had a chocolate Advent calendar.
It was first made in the 60s by Peter Trace, using wire coat hangers, tinsel and peppercorn jar lids as the drip trays for the candles.

Hide Ad
Advertisement
Hide Ad
It wasn’t the most beautiful of Christmas decorations, it looked alarmingly flimsy, and, with real candles, it was a serious fire hazard, but it was popular nonetheless.
If you are thinking of making this one, it would be wise to swap the real candles for some LED ones.
Dalek cake
Blue Peter presenters have shown viewers how to make numerous Doctor Who-inspired projects over the years, with the Time Lord’s greatest nemeses, the Daleks, featuring frequently.
One of the most inventive creations was the Dalek cake made by Valerie Singleton in 1966, using a swiss roll, some chocolate icing, cocktail sticks, liquorice, sweets and a glacé cherry.

Hide Ad
Advertisement
Hide Ad
The finished product was a bit wonky, and certainly less menacing than the real thing, but it also looked delicious.
